dt: {bc}a natural stream of water of usually considerable volume

dt: {bc}a concentrated band of water vapor that flows through the atmosphere and that is a significant part of the global {d_link|hydrologic cycle|hydrologic cycle} and an important source of regional precipitation

dt.t: Environment Canada is working on a new system to rank {wi}atmospheric rivers{/wi}, a type of weather system that damaged highways, flooded farms and homes, and left at least four people dead in southern B.C. earlier this week.

{wi}Atmospheric rivers{/wi} are relatively long, narrow regions in the atmosphere—like rivers in the sky—that transport most of the water vapor outside of the tropics. These columns of vapor move with the weather, carrying an amount of water vapor roughly equivalent to the average flow of water at the mouth of the Mississippi River. When the {wi}atmospheric rivers{/wi} make landfall, they often release this water vapor in the form of rain or snow.
In a typical year, significant {wi}atmospheric river{/wi} storms occur about 10 to 15 times in California. Ultimately, they account for up to 50% of the state's precipitation.

shortdef: a concentrated band of water vapor that flows through the atmosphere and that is a significant part of the global hydrologic cycle and an important source of regional precipitation

dt: lagoon in eastern Florida between the Canaveral Peninsula and Merritt Island

shortdef: lagoon in eastern Florida between the Canaveral Peninsula and Merritt Island
